milesmcdaniel projects recommendations writing

Here you will find various media that I think most people would enjoy. Some are works by creators you've mostly likely heard of before like J. R. R. Tolkein or Hayao Miyazaki. In this case I'm trying to promote the appreciation of some of their lesser-known creations.

Books

  • Children of Húrin by J. R. R. Tolkein — Ages before The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings trilogy in a land called Beleriand, Morgoth's evil will is creeping across the kingdoms of Men and Elves. Children of Húrin is grim and its protaganists are cursed. The story is more akin to a Greek tragedy than the mirth of The Hobbit.
  • Cloud Atlas by David Mitchell — Six wildy different stories from various locations and time periods are brilliantly interwoven in a way that you don't really begin to understand until you've nearly completed the book.
  • Endurance by Alfred Lansing — An absolutely incredible story about the survival of the members of the ill-fated Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition. The often-quoted (though never verified) advertisement: "Men wanted for hazardous journey. Low wages, bitter cold, long hours of complete darkness. Safe return doubtful. Honour and recognition in event of success."
  • Grokking Algorithms by Aditya Y. Bhargava — In my opinion this is the best introduction to algorithms. The author does a fantastic job with his illustrations breaking down basic concepts like Big O notation, sorts, and data structures. The book isn't comprehensive (e.g. it doesn't really cover searches) but I don't think that's a bad thing for what it is: a great introduction.
  • The Three-Body Problem by Cixin Liu — My favorite sci-fi novel written within the decade. If you're a fan of physics, computer science, or just interested in an original story concerning contact with extraterrestrial intelligence, pick this one up.
  • A Wild Sheep Chase by Haruki Murakami — A divorced advertiser receives a photo of a sheep. After publishing it, he is contacted by a well-connected individual who sends him on a quest to track down that sheep. I could have easily listed 3 or 4 Murakami novels here but I think this one makes a great introduction to his style of prose and magical realism.

Film and Television

  • The Castle of Cagliostro by Hayao Miyazaki — Definitely not one of Miyazaki's greater known works, but still has his charm, nonetheless. The film starts off with our protaganist, Lupin, who robs a casino only to find out the money is counterfeit. This leads him to the fictional microstate of Cagliostro where he manages to foil a tyrant, elude an Interpol inspector, and save a princess from an arranged marriage.
  • Cosmos: A Personal Voyage by Carl Sagan, Ann Druyan, and Steven Soter — Are you a fan of educational documentaries like BBC's Planet Earth? If so then you ought to give Cosmos a try. While there is a recent reboot featuring Neil deGrasse Tyson, I have not seen it and therefore cannot comment on it. Carl Sagan, the narrator, eloquently explains in layman's terms the nature of our universe and our humble place in it.
  • Dark by Baran bo Odar and Jantje Friese — This show focuses on a small German town and starts with a boy going missing. There's a cave, conspiracy, and time-traveling. Dark is indeed dark. If you watch this, I recommend putting on the original German audio with English subtitles as the dubbed English version is out of sync just enough to be annoying.
  • Dawn Wall by Josh Lowell and Peter Mortimer — The best climbing documentary I've seen. Beautifully shot and the story of how Tommy Caldwell and Keven Jorgeson came to climb the Dawn Wall in Yosemite is inspiring.
  • The Detectorists by Mackenzie Crook — This series is a comedy about a couple of metal detectorists in rural England. I never knew I wanted to try my hand at metal detecting before watching this show. Take note of the shows beautiful opening theme by Johnny Flynn.
  • Midnight Diner by Yarō Abe — I really don't know how better to describe this than saying it's like a wholesome Japanese version of Cheers. Each episode of Midnight Diner focuses on a dish that the chef makes and this is usually tied in somehow to the lives of his patrons. It's such a great show. I really don't understand how this isn't promoted by Netflix more.

Music

  • ***** by Les Cowboys Fringants — It's really hard to pick a singular album from this Québécois folk-rock band. Check out a couple tracks like Pizza galaxie or Entre deux taxis and branch out from there. Even if you're not so savvy on the French language, their sounds are catchy enough to keep you hooked.
  • ***** by Johnny Flynn — Once again I couldn't pick a single album so I'll leave you with a few track recommendations from this folksy Brit: Tickle Me Pink, Fol-De-Rol, and In Your Pockets
  • Eusa by Yann Tiersen — Perhaps better known for his work on the soundtracks of Amélie or Good Bye, Lenin!, his studio albums are world-class on their own right. Eusa is inspired by Ushant, an island off the coast of Yann Tiersen's native Brittany.
  • Innerspeaker by Tame Impala — Looking for a psychedelic cross between The Beatles and The Doors? Give this one a spin.
